<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 92, 101]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 895, 101]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will measure the spring constant \(k\) of a spring by two different methods. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 816, 133]]<|/det|> The spring constant \(k\) of a spring is a measure of how difficult the spring is to stretch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 203, 165]]<|/det|> **Method 1** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 177, 144, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 177, 623, 196]]<|/det|> Attach the spring to the clamp, as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 192, 556, 211]]<|/det|> Suspend a mass \(m = 500 \text{g}\) from the spring. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 220, 771, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 486, 532, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 166, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 518, 865, 536]]<|/det|> Pull the mass down a small distance (2–3 cm) from its rest position and release it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 440, 567]]<|/det|> The mass oscillates up and down. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 707, 598]]<|/det|> The period \(T\) of the oscillations is the time taken for one oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 611, 631, 629]]<|/det|> One complete oscillation of the mass is shown in Fig. 1.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 640, 779, 736]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 755, 532, 774]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 787, 180, 806]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 787, 900, 805]]<|/det|> Measure the time \(t\) taken for 20 oscillations. Do **not** remove the mass from the spring. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 817, 373, 836]]<|/det|> Record \(t\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 817, 920, 836]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 850, 541, 867]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 876, 824, 935]]<|/det|>
\(m/\mathrm {g}\)\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(T/\mathrm {s}\)
500

N/m [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 203, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 146, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 470, 180, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 470, 920, 504]]<|/det|> With the \(500\mathrm{g}\) mass still suspended from the spring, measure the stretched length \(l\) of the spring in centimetres to the nearest \(0.1\mathrm{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 515, 787, 534]]<|/det|> Do not include the loops at the ends of the spring in your measurement. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 373, 565]]<|/det|> Record \(l\) in Table 1.2. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 577, 541, 594]]<|/det|> Table 1.2 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 609, 717, 775]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the deviation of a ray of light passing through a transparent block and determine a quantity called the refractive index \(n\) of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 144, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 128, 529, 147]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 is on page 11 of your question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 160, 920, 195]]<|/det|>
- On Fig. 3.2, draw a normal to the line \(\mathbf{XY}\) at the point \(\mathbf{E}\). Extend your normal above and below \(\mathbf{XY}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 207, 567, 225]]<|/det|>
Measure the angle \(\theta\) between \(\mathbf{FE}\) and the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 237, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) ....................................................\(^\circ\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 146, 287]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 268, 920, 301]]<|/det|>
- Extend the line \(\mathbf{FE}\) until it almost meets the right-hand side of the page and label the end of the line \(\mathbf{G}\).

<label>•</label>

<label>•</label>

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 574, 354, 592]]<|/det|>

- Position the illuminated slit so that a ray of light passes along the line \(\mathbf{FE}\) towards \(\mathbf{E}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 918, 667]]<|/det|>

- Remove the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 758, 920, 791]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 175, 918, 211]]<|/det|>
The measurement of a quantity is reproducible if a similar result is obtained when the measurement is repeated by a different method or under different conditions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 216, 870, 250]]<|/det|>
Suggest how you can adapt this experiment to check if your value of \(\frac{d}{l}\) is reproducible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 252, 512, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
A student sets up a flexible track at the edge of a bench. The student investigates a metal ball as it rolls from rest down the track and travels through the air. The metal ball travels a horizontal distance \(d\) through the air and lands in a tray of sand placed on the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 144, 821, 163]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how one variable affects the size of this distance \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 176, 398, 194]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 208, 264, 225]]<|/det|>
· flexible track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 510, 241]]<|/det|>
· clamp, boss and stand to support the track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 358, 255]]<|/det|>
· selection of metal balls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 529, 287]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows how the flexible track is supported.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 295, 828, 572]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 584, 534, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 485, 633]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.
